speaker: F
text: Yeah. No, that's a great question, because if you think back and, you know, since the bitcoin white paper 14 years ago, you know, the policy making process is a slow one. Right. Which is in some ways good, because if they move too fast, they often get things wrong. And so time can be our friend here. What we've seen in the US over time is that the first step is that federal agencies look at the existing laws and the existing authorities they have and see how this new thing might apply. The first time we found that we saw this in the US was back in 2013, when the Financial Crimes Enforcement network talked about something called virtual currencies and convertible virtual currencies and explained that certain participants that that handle these are subject to the Bank Secrecy act. We've also seen the IR's provide guidance on how to do taxation of these assets. Even the SEC, as difficult as it is back in 2019, did put out a framework for analyzing digital assets with the Howey test. And so that is kind of the first action, is agencies will look at existing rules and then apply them. What we've seen over the past couple of years is there's been analysis going on through this executive order process or through the president's working group. More agencies have said, hey, there's some gaps in the laws and regulations. We probably need Congress to step in and fill those gaps. And there's two policies that come to the top of that list. One is figuring out how to do regulation of dollar backed stable coins. Yes, there's a lot of regulation that already exists. If you look at USDC issuer circle, they have money transmitter licenses, they're registered as money services business. They're doing their best to use the existing regulation. But it's probably nothing. Exactly the best way to go about making sure that there is a dollar in a bank account for every USDC coin in circulation. So I think that's probably the issue that could move the fastest in the new Congress next year. The other issue out there that there seems to be consensus that we need to step in and do is a way to regulate the crypto commodity spot markets. Pretty, pretty. There's pretty much consensus that bitcoin is a commodity. Most think that ether and most other cryptocurrencies that are listed on US exchanges are also commodities. The only person who doesn't think that is Gary Gensler at the SEC, who thinks everything's a security because he wants to regulate them as securities. But we need to figure out a way to have probably a federal regulator for those spot markets. And as part of that we could have attestations that they're properly custodying the crypto for their users and things of that nature. That's one that got an issue that did get a lot of attention this year. And there are several bills that would have addressed this. One is the Lummis Gillibrand Responsible Financial Innovation act that had some, some efforts. There's also the Digital Commodity Exchange act in the House, which is probably my favorite proposal out there. There was also this digital commodities Consumer Protection act that would have regulated centralized exchanges. The problem with that bill is it also captured a bunch of other entities that we don't think were being appropriately regulated. So that one, I think needs a lot of work if it's going to move forward. But yeah, these are all issues that I think Congress can get done in 2023, 2024 timeframe. And the good news is they're bipartisan. And the biggest issue and challenge I think we're going to have as an industry is making sure that they're focused on the actual problems and gaps and not expanded into things like DeFi or other parts of crypto where this type of regulation just doesn't make sense. Yeah, good, good, good.

text: Actually have a great question as well from our platform. Ralph H. On the RV website asks, where does the industry stand on starting a self regulatory organization akin to FINRA, otherwise known as the Financial Industry Regulation authority? What are your thoughts there, Kristen?

speaker: F
text: Yeah, so it's interesting. So a self regulatory organization, or SRO, it's actually like a very, very precise term. In order to have an SRO, you essentially need Congress and a regulatory agency to designate an organization to be the SRO. So even though it has the word self in it, the industry can't just decide to create an SRO. We have to have Congress say, all right, we want this agency to become either the SEC or the CFTC, to become the regulator of crypto, and then that agency designates an organization to become an SRO. So let's just say hypothetically that the SEC becomes the new regulator of crypto. The odds of them pointing that responsibility for the day to day monitoring of that regulation to a new organization, I think is very low. They would probably expand Finra's mandate similarly with the CFTC. They would probably look to the National Futures association to do that kind of work. So I think what we do need to be doing, though, is doing a better job talking about the standards that the industry and the best practices that the industry are working around. I think that's probably where the work is, as opposed to like a quote, unquote, self regulatory organization.

speaker: D
text: Fascinating. Well, thank you for that, Kristen. It's that time of the episode. Some people's favorite, other people's just the end, but it's time for my key takeaway. So let's get those horns of blaring and the spotlight swinging. So to me, obviously a very wide ranging conversation today. Absolutely fascinating to sit in on, listen to. But the two main things in my mind from listening to you, Christian, are education and patience. We got to have the patience to educate these congressmen and not have them just go by the seat of their pants. Start regulating with no real understanding of this space. We saw this with SBF and the fact that a lot of people sort of seem to be talking about it as it's defi, when it's really just out and out fraud, it seems like. And then lastly, the other thing that I thought was a great point, we have to make the US more attractive to these type of companies so that they are based in headquarters out of here and able to exist under proper regulation. Christian, anything I missed from there or anything you'd like to add?

speaker: F
text: No, no. I think. I think you got the key takeaways. The only other thing I would add is that I think that we can do this in DC. The industry has a presence. I think there's a lot of work that has been done. There are a lot of people who have been hired who are getting trained up to understand crypto, who are working on the process of educating policymakers. Like this is not a lost cause. It's certainly a setback. And it means that we're going to have to spend a lot of time rebuilding trust. But I do think that the pathway is there to get back to the point where we can start having conversations about what good, appropriate regulation should look like. And so I'm really excited for next year. I think that we've got a lot of work to do. Our mission is pretty clear, but it's going to take some time. But I think we'll be able to recover from, from the FTX disaster that we've all been dealing with over the past couple of weeks.

speaker: D
text: I love it. Cautious optimism. It's exactly where I'm at. I'm one of these people who is looking forward to this clarification, looking forward to more regulation so that this is the last of one of these major blow ups we have to deal with. Well, with that said, thank you, Kristen and Elaine. It's been a pleasure doing the show with you both. And that's it for today's show.
